schulte.kickerNote: Interactive focus and visual scanning practice
schulte.title: Schulte Table
schulte.subtitle: Play a browser-based Schulte Table trainer to practice visual search speed, attention switching, and steady scanning without leaving the site.

meta.title: Schulte Table (Play Online)
meta.description: Play a Schulte Table online in your browser with timer, mistakes, best times, and multiple grid sizes for focus and visual scanning practice.
meta.keywords: schulte table, focus game, brain exercise, visual scanning, attention training, online game

howToPlay.title: How To Play
howToPlay.step1: Pick a grid size from 3×3 up to 9×9 in the left panel, then start with a fresh board.
howToPlay.step2: Find and click the numbers in ascending order, starting from 1 and following the Next indicator.
howToPlay.step3: Use Restart to replay the same layout, New board for a reshuffle, and Highlight next number if you want an easier practice mode.
howToPlay.step4: Watch your timer, mistakes, and best time together, then move up to a larger grid once your accuracy stays consistent.

whyUse.title: Why People Use It
whyUse.body1: Schulte Tables are commonly used as a visual search and attention exercise. They are popular in reading and concentration practice because they force structured scanning across a grid.
whyUse.body2: Treat this as a practice tool, not a medical or diagnostic tool. Improvements in this game do not automatically guarantee broad cognitive improvement in everyday tasks.

notes.title: Practice Notes
notes.item1: Short rounds (1-3 minutes) usually work better than long sessions when your goal is consistency and focus.
notes.item2: If your eyes feel tired, stop and take a short break before the next round.
notes.item3: Use mistakes + time together. Faster is only meaningful if accuracy stays stable.

research.title: Research Notes
research.body1: Schulte Tables are best understood as a structured visual-search and attention exercise. They are useful because they give a repeatable task with measurable outcomes (time + errors).
research.body2: Research on attention and cognitive training is more nuanced than many productivity claims suggest. Task performance can improve with practice, but transfer to broader cognitive outcomes may be limited or mixed depending on study design and outcome measures.

stroop.kickerNote: Color-word interference and reaction control practice
stroop.title: Stroop Test
stroop.subtitle: Play a browser-based Stroop Test to challenge cognitive control, reaction speed, and focus by matching the ink color instead of the written word.

meta.title: Stroop Test (Play Online)
meta.description: Play a Stroop Test online in your browser with practice, standard, and timed modes, plus score, accuracy, and reaction-time tracking.
meta.keywords: stroop test, stroop effect, brain exercise, reaction game, cognitive control, online game

howToPlay.title: How To Play
howToPlay.step1: Pick a mode from the left panel, then start a fresh round when you are ready.
howToPlay.step2: Look at the ink color of the word, not the word itself, and tap the matching color button.
howToPlay.step3: Use Restart to replay the current mode immediately, or switch modes for a different pace and trial count.
howToPlay.step4: Track score, mistakes, accuracy, and average reaction time together instead of chasing speed alone.

whyUse.title: Why People Use It
whyUse.body1: The Stroop task is widely used as a cognitive-control exercise because it forces you to suppress the automatic urge to read the word and respond to the font color instead.
whyUse.body2: Treat this as a fast attention and inhibition practice tool, not a medical or diagnostic assessment. Better game scores do not automatically mean broad real-world cognitive gains.

notes.title: Practice Notes
notes.item1: Short sessions usually work better than long streaks when the goal is clean focus and consistent responses.
notes.item2: If you start guessing, slow down and re-center on the ink color before continuing.
notes.item3: Use accuracy and reaction time together. Fast mistakes are still weak reps.

research.title: Research Notes
research.body1: The Stroop effect is a classic interference task: reading is automatic, while naming the ink color requires more control. That conflict is why the task is still used in attention and executive-control research.
research.body2: As with other cognitive-training tasks, improvement inside the game is easy to measure, but transfer to broader cognitive benefits is more nuanced and depends on context, study design, and outcome measures.

trainer.rule: Match the color of the text, not the word you read.
trainer.tip: Tip: if the word pulls your attention, pause for a beat and answer the ink color only.
trainer.tipWithHint: Tip: keep your eyes on the ink color first. The hint line is there to reinforce the rule while you warm up.
